lcInstruction.p: The DITA concept topic is used to provide information about a particular subject. As such, concept topics contain basic DITA elements, such as paragraphs, lists, images, tables, and many others. Most of these elements can be used in the other topic types (task, reference, and glossary), as well.
The minimal concept topic contains a <concept> root element (with an id attribute) that contains a <title> element.
Following the <title> element and an optional <shortdesc> or <abstract> element, use a <conbody> element to contain the concept content.

step.cmd: Make a copy of the file 1_new_concept.dita and open it in your editor.

info.note: If you are using a DITA-aware text editor, make sure you are in text mode, rather than Author or visual mode.

stepxmp.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="my_first_concept">
</concept>

info.p: The first line (which begins with <?xml) is an XML declaration, which is a standard part of all XML files.

The second line is the DOCTYPE declaration, which tells DITA editors or DITA output generators that this is a concept topic. The programs then use that information when validating the content of the topic.

step.cmd: Inside the <concept> element, add a <title> element, and add the concept title.

stepxmp.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="my_first_concept"> <title>Wild duck species</title>
</concept>

step.info: As you have probably read before, the <conbody> contains all the actual content in the concept.

stepxmp.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="my_first_concept"> <title>Wild duck species</title> <conbody>
</conbody> </concept>
